data_findings.finding: This is a 2D irregular polygon packing problem - pack Christmas tree shapes into smallest square bounding box for N=1 to 200. Score = sum(side^2/n). Tree shape is a 15-vertex polygon with trunk and 3 tiers. Key approaches: 1) Simulated annealing with local search, 2) Genetic algorithms, 3) Bottom-left heuristics, 4) No-fit polygon (NFP) for collision detection, 5) Compaction/squeeze operations. Top kernels use C++ compiled binaries (bbox3, tree_packer) for speed.

Academic research shows: 1) Extended local search with nonlinear programming, 2) Collision-free region (CFR) placement, 3) Simulated annealing controls sequence and placement, 4) Two-level algorithms (inner: fixed container, outer: adjust container size), 5) Tabu search to avoid local minima. Key insight: place items on CFR vertices for optimal compaction.

Key kernels use pre-compiled binaries: bbox3 (main optimizer), shake_public (shaking/perturbation), tree_packer (SA-based). The workflow is: 1) Start with good baseline CSV, 2) Run bbox3 with parameters -n (iterations) -r (restarts), 3) Apply fix_direction (rotation optimization), 4) Run shake_public for perturbation, 5) Validate and repair overlaps. Score ~70.6 achievable with binaries, target 68.89 requires novel approaches.

Discussion 'Why the winning solutions will be Asymmetric' (39 votes) suggests asymmetric solutions outperform symmetric ones for this packing problem. This is a key insight for algorithm design - don't assume rotational symmetry in optimal solutions.

web_research.query: What are the best algorithms for irregular polygon packing optimization in 2D?
web_research.finding:
Gli algoritmi più efficaci per l'ottimizzazione del packing di poligoni irregolari in 2D sono spesso basati su approcci euristici, metaeuristici e metodi esatti, a seconda della complessità e delle specifiche del problema. Tra le tecniche più note vi sono gli algoritmi genetici combinati con metodi lineari, come descritto in uno studio che propone un approccio ibrido di genetico e programmazione lineare per ottimizzare il packing irregolare ([MDPI](https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/13/22/12474)). Inoltre, i metodi di ricerca locale estesa, come quelli basati sulla programmazione non lineare e sul simulated annealing, sono stati efficaci nel trovare soluzioni competitive e migliorare risultati noti, anche minimizzando il materiale di scarto ([ScienceDirect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0305054811001596), [Springer](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10479-013-1341-4)). 

Altri approcci includono heuristici come l'algoritmo di Djang e Finch adattato per il
